question_templates: What theme do these two passages share?
How is the theme of {theme} developed differently in each text?
Compare how each author explores the idea of {theme}.

passage1.title: The Marathon
passage1.text: At mile 20, Jasmine's legs burned and her lungs ached. She wanted to quit. Then she remembered her grandfather's words: 'The finish line doesn't move—you have to.' She put one foot in front of the other until she crossed that line.

passage2.title: Learning Piano
passage2.text: For months, the same song sounded terrible no matter how much Aiden practiced. His fingers wouldn't cooperate. But every day, he sat at the piano again. One morning, something clicked. The music flowed. All those hours finally paid off.

paired_passages.comparison: Both show characters struggling but continuing despite difficulty. The marathon shows physical perseverance; the piano shows learning perseverance.

passage1.title: The Art Project
passage1.text: When paired with Miguel, Zoe groaned. He always wanted to do things differently. But his unusual ideas made their project unique. They won first place, and Zoe realized that different perspectives create better results.

passage2.title: The New Neighbor
passage2.text: The Sharma family's cooking smelled strange to Tyler at first. But when Mrs. Sharma invited him to try her food, he discovered amazing new flavors. Now Friday dinners at the Sharmas' are his favorite tradition.

paired_passages.comparison: Both show characters initially resistant to differences who learn to appreciate them. One focuses on ideas; the other on culture.

comparison_passages.title: Two Leaders
comparison_passages.text: Maria led with enthusiasm, always the first to volunteer and rally others with her energy. James led quietly, listening more than speaking, but when he did speak, everyone paid attention. Both got results, but in very different ways.
comparison_passages.difference: Maria leads loudly; James leads quietly

comparison_passages.title: City and Country
comparison_passages.text: Mia grew up surrounded by skyscrapers and subway sounds. Noah grew up with open fields and starry nights. When they met at camp, Mia taught Noah about museums and pizza slices. Noah taught Mia about fishing and campfires. Both realized there was so much they had never experienced.
comparison_passages.effect: Their different backgrounds gave them different skills and perspectives to share

question_templates: How does the narrator's point of view affect the story?

pov_examples.title: The Secret
pov_examples.first_person_limited: I knew something was wrong the moment Mom came home. Her smile seemed fake, and she kept checking her phone. I asked what was going on, but she just said 'Nothing, honey.' I didn't believe her.
pov_examples.third_person_omniscient: Mom came home with a secret she couldn't share yet—a surprise party for Dad's birthday. She hated lying to her curious daughter, but it would be worth it. Meanwhile, her daughter suspected something was terribly wrong.
pov_examples.analysis: First person creates suspense because we don't know the truth. Third person omniscient removes the mystery but shows both perspectives.

question_templates: What evidence does the author use to support the claim that {claim}?
Is the author's reasoning logical? Explain.
What additional evidence could strengthen the author's argument?

argument_passages.title: School Should Start Later
argument_passages.text: Schools should start later for middle and high school students. Research shows that teenagers need 8-10 hours of sleep, but their natural sleep cycle makes them stay up later. Early start times mean students are sleep-deprived, which hurts their grades and health. Schools that shifted to later start times saw test scores improve by 15% and car accidents drop significantly.
argument_passages.reasoning: Sleep deprivation hurts performance; later starts allow more sleep; data shows improvement

argument_passages.title: Reduce Plastic Use
argument_passages.text: We must reduce single-use plastics. Every year, 8 million tons of plastic enter our oceans, harming marine life. Sea turtles mistake plastic bags for jellyfish and eat them. Fish consume tiny plastic particles that end up in our food. Many countries have already banned plastic bags, reducing waste by millions of tons.
evidence: plastic ends up in our food
argument_passages.reasoning: Plastic harms animals and humans; solutions exist and work

account1.text: The Eagles dominated from start to finish, outplaying the Tigers in every quarter. Their superior strategy and teamwork led to a well-deserved 3-1 victory.

account2.text: Despite a strong effort, the Tigers fell 3-1 to the Eagles. Two questionable referee calls shifted momentum, and a key player's injury in the second half hurt the team's chances.

multiple_accounts.differences: The winning team's account emphasizes skill; the losing team's account emphasizes bad luck and unfair calls

fluency_passages.text: The ancient library held secrets that had been forgotten for centuries. Dust motes danced in the streams of light that filtered through stained glass windows. Maya ran her fingers along the leather spines of books older than her great-grandmother. Somewhere in these shelves was the answer she sought—a map to the hidden garden that her family had protected for generations. She just had to find it before the developers did.
